ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: High efficiency silicon nitride grating coupler

Affiliation.OrgName: A*STAR (Agency for Science, Technology and Research)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper, we have designed, fabricated and characterized silicon nitride grating couplers with high efficiency at 1490 nm. The devices are fabricated using deep UV photolithography with resolution requirement of ∼500 nm. The grating coupler fabricated yields a peak coupling efficiency of −5.1 dB. The 1-dB bandwidth of the grating coupler is 60 nm.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Nanophotonics has attracted substantial attention and interest in recent years in various promising applications, including optical communications, optical interconnect, signal processing and sensing [1–5]. Low-loss high-index contrast waveguides are the basic building blocks for on-chip compact photonic integrated circuit (PIC) for its submicron-sized footprint. Waveguides on silicon-on-insulator platform and silicon nitride (Si3N4) that are fabricated by complementary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS) compatible processes have been reported in past few years [6–9]. However, it is challenging to couple light from optical fibers to the compact waveguides efficiently due to the large mode mismatch between these tiny waveguides and relatively large optical fibers (submicron vs. a few microns). Edge coupling using nanotapers [9–11] and top coupling using grating coupler [12, 13] are two major approaches to achieve efficient optical coupling. Between these two approaches, the grating coupler obviates the need for edge facets, allowing for on-wafer testing and simplifying processing; hence it is an attractive candidate for standard optical coupler. Inspiring developments for silicon (Si) grating coupler have been reported by various groups. [14–19] However, there are limited reports for Si3N4 grating coupler [21, 22]. Si3N4 has a refractive index of ∼2.0 that is significantly smaller than that of Si, yet it still allows for highly compact PICs. The fabrication tolerance for Si3N4 is higher than for Si and has a lower dimension resolution requirement due to its relative low index. Due to the index contrast of Si3N4 and cladding material, Si3N4-based photonic devices are polarization-dependent, same as Si photonic devices, i.e. important device parameters like the propagation rate and coupling strength of the guided TE and TM modes are different [23]. In this paper, we have designed high-efficiency Si3N4 grating couplers at 1490 nm for TE polarization. The device is fabricated using single etch for fabrication process simplicity and requires fabrication resolution of about 500 nm. The grating couplers are finally characterized in experiment and presented.

Section1.Heading: Design and simulation
Section1.Para:
For conventional Si grating couplers, partial etching of waveguide is normally required to optimize the grating coupling strength. For Si3N4 grating, a fully etched profile is sufficient to provide an appropriate coupling strength, which greatly simplifies the fabrication process. Figure 1(a) shows the cross-sectional view of a single etched Si3N4 grating coupler on a Si substrate with a buried oxide (BOX) layer. The waveguide is covered with a cladding material (here we use SiO2). The filling factor is defined as the ratio of the remained grating width g to the grating period Λ. We employed two-dimensional (2D) finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) numerical simulations for such grating structures as shown in Fig. 1(b). The refractive indices of the Si3N4 and oxide are 2.0 and 1.45, respectively. The grating pitch is 1.05 μm, and the filling factor is 0.55. The BOX thickness is 2.6 μm. The grating is also covered with a 2.0 μm oxide upper cladding. The grid size is 20 nm and the input light wavelength is set to be 1490 nm. Coupling efficiency between the fiber and waveguide was calculated using the power in the waveguide mode coming out from the grating coupler. Here we obtained a coupling efficiency of about 55.5 %. It should be noted that the designed grating couples light equally to both top and bottom directions due to its fully etched profile, which results in a 3-dB excess loss. A further improvement in coupling efficiency is expected by putting in a bottom reflection mirror to reflect light upwards [24].
Fig. 1
(a) Schematic of a Si3N4 grating coupler; (b) simulation profile of a Si3N4 grating coupler

The design procedure is summarized as follows. The grating period Λ is the first parameter to be carefully designed to optimize coupling strength in order to realize Gaussian-like output field profile with a desired coupling angle θ. To satisfy the Bragg condition at first-order diffraction, the grating period is being chosen as
$\frac{1}{\varLambda} = \frac{n_{\mathrm{eff}}}{\lambda} - \frac{n_{\mathrm{c}}\sin \theta}{ \lambda}$ , where n eff is the effective index of the grating, n c, the refractive index of cladding material and λ the center wavelength [20]. For our experimental setup and also conventional preference, θ is preferred to be 6∼10∘. Figure 2(a) shows the coupling efficiency when varying the grating period Λ at a fill factor f of 50 %. The grating period Λ is then chosen to be 1.05 μm, comparing the obtained light coupling profile with a preferred angle θ. Secondly, the influence of filling factor is numerically studied by assuming the same Λ to further optimize the coupling strength. The simulated spectra with filling factor ranging from 30 to 80 % are shown in Fig. 2(b) and the preferred filling factor is found to be around 55 %. In addition, the distance from the Si3N4 layer to the underneath substrate layer, i.e. BOX thickness, also has a great impact on the coupling strength due to constructive or destructive interference with the reflection from substrate surface. It is observed that the upward coupled light intensity shows a periodic behavior with a period of 0.5 μm as shown in Fig 2(c). The BOX thickness is then chosen to be 2.6 μm to have good confinement of light in Si3N4 waveguide. Lastly, the broadband spectrum of the designed grating is shown in Fig 2(d) with the optimized parameters and the central wavelength is found to be 1483 nm with a coupling efficiency of 55.95 % (corresponding to a −2.52-dB coupling loss).

Section1.Heading: Fabrication
Section1.Para:
The grating couplers were fabricated on an 8-inch Si wafer with a BOX layer with the optimized thickness of 2.6 μm using standard CMOS processes. A Si3N4 layer with 400 nm thickness was deposited by low-pressure chemical vapor deposition system. The waveguide structures were first patterned by optical lithography using a 248-nm Nikon Scanner and then etched using reactive ion etching (RIE) to the BOX surface. The fully etched grating couplers were obtained together with the waveguide structure in a single etching step. This is useful for device performance uniformity control and cost-effective fabrication in wafer-scale. Next, 2-μm SiO2 was deposited using plasma enhanced vapor deposition system on the wafer as the top cladding. Figure 3 shows the SEM images of the Si3N4 grating coupler with 15 periods fabricated before the cladding deposition.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para: The Si3N4 grating couplers fabricated were characterized by measuring the insertion loss of a straight waveguide with grating couplers at both ends. Two cleaved single mode fibers with a diameter of about 10 μm tilted at 8∘ were used as optical input and output. The grating region was 12-μm wide, which was gradually tapered from a 1-μm-wide waveguide by a adiabatic linear taper with a length of 500 μm. The total length of each device was 2.9 mm. A tunable laser (Agilent 8164B) was employed as the input light source. The scanning range of laser was from 1400 to 1600 nm with a resolution of 0.1 nm and a 500-ms settling time for each step. The input light was adjusted to TE-polarization using a polarization controller. No index-matching liquid was applied during the experiments. All the measured data were normalized to the fiber–fiber insertion loss of the laser source and the polarizer that excludes the possible extra loss from the cleaved fibers and connectors. The measured propagation loss for the straight single-mode strip Si3N4 waveguide fabricated in the platform with a width of 1 μm was ∼0.72 dB/cm. The ∼2-mm waveguide and gradual tapers were thus taken as lossless given the negligible propagation loss of Si3N4 waveguide. In addition, it was assumed that the input and output grating couplers have the same coupling for the symmetric testing setup.

Figure 4(a) shows the measured coupling loss for Si3N4 grating coupler as a function of period versus filling factor. It is observed that a filling factor of 55 % (refers to the unetched part) is optimal and the spectrum agrees well with the simulation results. Variation of period (in a step of 50 nm) leads to large increment of coupling loss as the Bragg condition is no longer satisfied [16]. In addition, Fig. 4(b) shows the measured coupling loss as a function of wavelength for filling factors of 50, 55 and 60 %. The minimum coupling loss is −5.1 dB (corresponding to 30.9 % coupling efficiency) with a 1-dB bandwidth of 60 nm. Larger filling factor results in a wavelength red-shift of the peak position with a minor influence on coupling loss at the peak position. This is reasonable as a wavelength to fulfill the Bragg condition should always exist for a given grating period and given fiber angle. The central wavelength at a filling factor of 55 % is about 1480 nm, which agrees well with the simulation result of 1483 nm. The coupling loss of experiment is higher than the simulation value and we attributed this to the following reasons. First, the power recorded in the simulation was intensity only and not considering the actual mode profile in fiber coupling that may have additional loss. Second, the imperfect etched waveguide profile, which is different from the ideal case such as the roughness and slanted sidewall, will affect the coupling efficiency. Last but not the least, there are additional loss resources such as finite distance from fiber to grating surface, reflection from the grating surface and insertion loss from connectors in the experimental setup.
Fig. 4
Experiment results: coupling loss of a Si3N4 grating coupler versus (a) filling factor as a function of period; (b) wavelength as a function of filling factor

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: A high-efficiency fiber-to-waveguide grating coupler designed on Si3N4 platform is reported. The fabrication process is compatible with conventional CMOS technology using deep UV photolithography (248 nm). The measured coupling loss is −5.1 dB, which corresponds to a 30.9 % coupling efficiency. The 1-dB bandwidth is 60 nm. It should be noted that a great portion of light is traveling downwards and is lost due to the fully etched grating. Further improvement can be achieved by adding bottom mirrors to reflect light upwards. Our effort in this direction is currently ongoing.
